title-group.article-title: Why Narrative? Which Narrative? Struggling with Time and Place in Life and Research

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1999 The Ontario Institute for Studies in Education

abstract.p: Describing how my way of being in the world hindered or advanced my research, I suggest that a researcher's quality of life and mode of narrative inquiry may be closely related. The outcome seems to hinge on the inquirer's relationship to time and place in life and research. As all human beings, researchers use narrative to structure temporal complexity, only to find that this use contributes a complexity of its own. Efforts to overcome either pervade our lives as well as our forms of inquiry. I specify how such efforts endanger narrative inquiry, both in research and teacher education, and I struggle to find a language that accommodates a contextualized, narrative self as it reaches out to culturally shared conditions.

Beattie and Conle (1996)

Stephen Hawking, in his book A Brief History of Time (1988), asserts that after Einstein, scientists no longer envision a time that is absolute, a time that presents the backdrop for our lives. Time appears to run more slowly near massive bodies like the earth (p. 32). "It appeared that each observer must have his own measure of time" (p. 21). "Time became a more personal concept, relative to the observer who measured it" (p. 144) 32
